captions.text:
It&#39;s always nice when a random game really
grabs me, it&#39;s like hitting it off with an

attractive stranger in a bar who doesn&#39;t keep
an eye on their drink and doesn&#39;t question

my unmarked van. And I thought it might be
educational to list some things it DIDN&#39;T

do to grab me, games industry: it didn&#39;t put
out a prerendered trailer six years before

release showcasing all its crazy characters
with magenta coloured partial buzzcuts, it

didn&#39;t use an aggressive levelling system
to increase engagement the way a drug dealer

&quot;increases engagement&quot; by cutting the blow
with laundry detergent, and it doesn&#39;t have

Batman in it, no, what it did was, it made
me emotionally engage with it. I play a game

like Gears of War where I&#39;m in a constant
life or death struggle with snarling monsters

that want to exterminate humanity and I&#39;m
more emotionally engaged with the cheese and

pickle sandwich I&#39;m taking sneaky bites of
between reloads. It kills off a main character,

I feel more remorse when my wife notices pickle
stains on the dog. In contrast, I played Spiritfarer,

got to the part where an old hedgehog with
dementia remembers who I am in the brief moment

before she disappears, and I cried. I actually
did. Fuck you.

I played Spiritfarer at E3 and I remember
it did a really fucking shitty job of bringing

across what the fuck it was, so let&#39;s see
if I can do better. We play as Stella, a constantly

smiling young girl with a hat slightly larger
than she is, and a second player can optionally

play as Stella&#39;s cat. I&#39;ll take completely
unnecessary multiplayer modes for 200, Alex.

Ooh, what is Mario Odyssey? Stella has been
appointed as the new ferryman on the river

Styx. Possibly as the result of a heavily
exaggerated resume. Her job is now to pilot

a houseboat around a sea of fantastical places
and creatures, giving rides to the spirits

of the newly dead in the form of animal people
and helping them finish off their last few

concerns before taking them to eternal rest.
And it seems that an awful lot of people&#39;s

unresolved issues in life revolve around fetch
quests. We might as well categorise Spiritfarer

as an &quot;arty indie game&quot; but for once we play
as a small child in a not scary world. Quite

a nice world, actually, all hand drawn in
a lovely clean art style that reminds me of

Franco-Belgian cartoons. Full of light and
wonder and melancholy humour which does rather

juxtapose against the underlying knowledge
that our job is essentially to take our passengers

one by one into the woods and ice them in
the back of the head.

I&#39;d also group Spiritfarer with Gris and Sea
of Solitude under the subheading of &quot;very

metaphorical arty indie games.&quot; But here&#39;s
how it doesn&#39;t fuck it up like those two did:

One, it never beats you around the head with
its underlying meaning, Sea of Solitude; Two,

it has a deeper and more poignant underlying
meaning than &quot;main character is a little bit

sad,&quot; GRIS. Three, it treats its gameplay
as a way to establish its themes and add greater

weight to its emotional moments, rather than
a bunch of meaningless checkpoint flags to

fill the space between the metaphors, GRIS
AND Sea of Solitude. And four, meta. Meta,

phor. The main point is, Spiritfarer has both
underlying AND surface meaning. If you want,

you can forget all about the metaphor business,
I&#39;m certainly fucking sick of saying the word.

If you want, it could just be a story about
a little girl on a magical adventure, making

a bunch of animal friends, hanging out, doing
their sidequests, hugging them with the dedicated

Hug button, then icing them in the woods.
And then you feel sad because you&#39;re actually

sad about never getting to see your friend
again. Not because there&#39;s a huge symbolic

statue of the main character telling you to
be sad. GRIS again.

Let&#39;s head down to the core gameplay in my
magic diving bell. It&#39;s a 2D platforming base

building exploration craft your way up the
tech tree &#39;em up structurally reminiscent

of, say, Subnautica. Craft upgrades to explore
more of the map to find new resources to craft

more upgrades. How it differs from Subnautica
is that you carry your base around with you

on your ship and all the sea monsters actually
sincerely want to be your friend and aren&#39;t

just saying that to get you into devouring
range. There&#39;s also some Stardew Valley in

here since you have to grow crops, cook meals
and feed your passengers the things they like

to keep the ungrateful dying bastards happy.
The primary gameplay loop is a workaday routine

that your passengers are woven into just enough
to get you used to seeing them around, and

that&#39;s why it&#39;s an emotional lurch when it&#39;s
time to take them behind the woodshed. &#39;Cos

when you get back from seeing off Dennis the
Slug, for a while you&#39;re not harvesting lettuce

anymore, you&#39;re harvesting the lettuce Dennis
the Slug used to like. You can&#39;t do the stud

farm minigame without thinking about how Dennis
the Slug taught you the optimal method for
bringing off a horse.

And of course that lovely house you built
for Dennis the Slug stands empty on your boat

for the rest of the game, and by the end your
ship is struggling to stay afloat under the

weight of countless two-storey tombstones,
just as our souls are burdened with the memories

of times past both good and bad until the
day we let it go. Metaphoooors! (Ding) Oops!

I think I heard the bell! That means it&#39;s
time to qualify that praise! Spiritfarer might

be a little bit too proud of its hand-drawn
animation. A lot of the workaday activities

have animations that go on just a bit too
long. Endearing as it is to watch Stella boggle

in wonder as her magic oven gloves appear,
three hundred times later I wish she&#39;d fucking

get over it at last so I could just have my
fucking cheese sticks. I&#39;m also annoyed by

the way the game insists that we go to sleep
at night. Yahtzee, that&#39;s when most people

go to sleep, genius. But there&#39;s no exhaustion
meter or any particular reason to go to sleep

except your boat stubbornly refuses to move
when it&#39;s dark and I&#39;d really rather be getting

on with shit. The cited reason is that Stella
can&#39;t navigate when it&#39;s dark, but during

the day she seems to manage perfectly well
even when milking in the cowshed with her
head halfway up Daisy&#39;s arse.

Also, while the story as brought across by
the atmosphere and visuals is very effective,

it falls short in the dialogue. It&#39;s a bit
overwritten. Yes, the final monologue before

a character gets iced is usually a bit of
a knee in the feely parts, but at other times

there are too many characters whose quirk
is that they talk too much. Accidentally press

&quot;Talk&quot; instead of &quot;Buy&quot; while interacting
with the merchant and you&#39;re locked into the

mash message skip mambo for thirty seconds.
Finally, Spiritfarer fails to stick the landing.

Once you&#39;ve iced enough motherfuckers you
get a sequence that reveals a significant

truth about Stella and it&#39;s the high point
where the game should&#39;ve ended. Sadly the

nature of the beast means it instead goes
&quot;Right, when you&#39;re done finishing off your

last few grindy sidequests come back here
to end the game properly.&quot; And then Stella&#39;s

journey inevitably dribbles limply to a conclusion
at the point when you get bored and decide

to pack it in. All the emotion in the process
of resolving your last passenger is lost as

you&#39;re thinking &quot;Yeah, just hurry up and have
a fucking epiphany, asshole, some of us have

places to be.&quot; Nevertheless, I recommend Spiritfarer.
In this numb unsympathetic world, anything

that makes me feel something is worth celebrating.
That&#39;s why I don&#39;t take the price tags off
my underpants.
